dialogues.speaker: EXT. CITY ISLAND THE BRONX DAY

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: City Island is a fishing village, located in the Bronx, New York, a place most people associate with machete’s, chop-shops, the Son of Sam, gang warfare and the once great New York Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Bronx is all these things. But it is also home to the families that are the infra- structure of the greatest city in the world— the fireman, the cab-drivers, the sanitation workers, the secretaries, the teachers and the cops. And the guys who work in our local prisons. Like myself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locals opening their shops in the morning, bidding each other a good day.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now: City Island is distinct from the rest of the Bronx by virtue of being located on it’s own two lane spit, right in the middle of the Sound. Most people don’t believe it until they see it. And within the one square mile that comprises all there is of City Island lies another distinction. That of the muscle-sucker versus the clam digger.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The ‘muscle-sucker’ is an island resident who moved here from somewhere else. The ‘clam- digger’, however, was born and bred on City Island, preferably in the same house that’s been handed down through the generations. Myself, I'm a clam-digger. There’s quite a few of us. Houses don’t go up for sale here everyday. My grandparents built our house in 1924. My dad grew up here. So did I. My kids did too. And this goes to the heart of why it matters so much to a clam-digger to be what he is and not some mussel-sucker.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because we represent family, continuity, stability. And in the Bronx—hell, in the world as we know it—these qualities are in increasingly short supply. In short, the world can be divided between clam-diggers and mussel suckers. Those who stay, and those who wander. But I digress. You asked me my worst secret. My most personal secret. The secret of all my secrets. Well..like most of us, I guess I have a few. From an upstairs side-window, we see SMOKE. Not billowing or threatening, just gently emerging from the window.

dialogues.text: Then my brother had an affair with my stepfather who met my mother in re-hab—-this was pre-Liz & Fortensky and I was sent away to boarding school in Switzerland and— (her cell rings-she answers) Hello? (pause, she smiles) Well hello Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I’m callin’ you on a whim. I was thinking maybe we could work on our secrets thing. You know? Tell you the truth... (pause, then) I’m a little stuck. With what to do with my son and everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY (into phone) My brother? Overdosed on heroin in the mens room of the diner on forty- second and tenth? Hold his hand and tell him I’m on my way! I’1l be there in ten minutes, Vincent! (to her date) I’m sorry, you understand, we’ll re-sked when I’m avail. And she's off, leaving a bewildered date in her wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VINCE (confused) Scuse me? But the phone is dead. Vince’s face: a slow smile as he realizes that she just dumped a guy to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The strip-club where Vivian works. She storms in, pulling hair out of its bun. BRUNO the bartender smiles at her. The place is packed with a drunken, boorish Saturday night crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Spring break over?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Do me a favor? Ask Autumn if she wants to go home early tonight and aplit her shift with me.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNO
dialogues.text: Highly unlikely. Asian invasion is out in force. He nods with his head. Vivian looks. A table of a dozen Asian businessmen are tipping Autumn with hundred dollar bills. She’s lapdancing three, simultaneously.  41 VIVIAN (bitterly) Shit! I coulda cleaned up this weekend. He pours her a drink. She lights a cigarette and does the drink in one big gulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce exits from the kitchen and sits on a lounge chair. She has a pack of cigarettes and a glass of wine in her hand. She sits and looks up as she sees— TONY is sitting across the yard in the fold out chair. He sees her. Nods a greeting.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Nods back. Lights a cigarette. JOYCE (across yard) My husband thinks I quit. Tony’s face: a private smile at his realization that Vinc and Joyce are equally guilty. TONY (yells across yard) One good thing about the joint—they don’t let you smoke anymore. I quit.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Bein’ in prison and not bein’ able to smoke? That must be like..bein’ in jail. An odd pause as Tony considers this. 57. INT. VINCE JR.’s ROOM Vince Jr. is on-line. The site is: REAL CENTERFOLDS! Lots of pictures of blonde, bronzed, California models. His ey not interested. And worried too. Then— Vince Jr. types in “DENISEBBW.COM” and waits. A moment later, there’s the fat neighbor! He stares, both fascinat and ashamed. DENISE (on internet) Hi! I’m Denise and I’m a proud BBW. That's “big beautiful woman” for those of you new to this. I’m Five-eight, three-hundred and fifty pounds and I think eating and being a big beautiful woman is the sexiest thing in the world! If you join my club, you'll get twenty-  42 four hour access to a live image of my kitchen, where I spend most of my time when I’m not working. As she continues, Vince Jr. grabs a credit card belonging VINCENT RIZZO that he keeps displayed quite openly on his desk and enters the numbers. Hits JOIN NOW. He waits. Energized! Digging it! 58. INT. DINER WEST 42"? Street. NIGHT Vince and Molly, drinking coffee, eating French fries. A copy of BACKSTAGE is on the table.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: He’s a good guy, you can tell. Must have had a hell of a time with Nan. Wasn't like I was any help. (pause, then) Only thing is he still don’t know..who I am.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You must tell him, Vincent. Think of the drama of the moment. On the other hand, think of the drama of not telling him. Wait! Don’t think of anything, for Godssake! (she closes her eyes—and then) No. You must tell him. The longer he doesn’t know your true identity, the greater the sense of betrayal. He’s been betrayed enough. VINCE (guiltily) All started with me walkin’ out on him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, don’t succumb to self-flagellation. I mean I understand it—it’s wonderfully Catholic, but you’re beyond it. You've opened up your home to a convicted felon. You’ve even shown him great trust by leaving him alone with your family. VINCE (dawning) Jesus.  43

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Because he’s your blood and if you can’t trust your blood, what the hell can you trust? Now you must take the final step and reveal his birthright to him. She inhales, satisfied that the decision is correct. Smil at Vince. A beat. He smiles back at her. One of those sha smiles that could go just about anywhere. Vince lowers his eyes first. They fall on her copy of ‘BACKSTAGE’, sitting on the table between them.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Ugh. It’s an addiction. “Backstage”-- the Wall Street Journal for struggling actors. You peruse it for news on open calls for parts you won’t get in projects that are never made. For instance: (as she opens it and reads) Open call: Male, age 30-50, working- class type, no agency rep. required. Monday, 9 am, Canal Street Armory. (pause, thoughtfully) Hm. That one might be good for you.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: What happens—how’s it work?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You've never auditioned? Oh Vincent, it’s dreadful. You go and wait in a room crowded with people who look vaguely familiar. They march you in. They stare at you. They hate you. You sing and dance and show off all of the talent that once thrilled your mother and father. They make faces. Sometimes they ask a question—very rarely. You're dismissed. You leave feeling like a failure.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Sounds...scary.  44

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Having said that..you really should go on this one. It sounds perfect for you. She tears out the ad. Gives it to Vince who reads it. Intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO PORCH NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tony and Joyce drinking wine, staring at the water and th view of the city.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You must think we’re a bunch of—

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, no, not at all.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I mean, we don’t always act like a bunch of-—

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, forget it I..I understand. Long pause. Then, with radical simplicity—

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Families are tough. Joyce looks at Tony. Appreciates his calm stoicism. 60. INT. VINCE JR.’S ROOM Vince Jr. is staring at the site. A spinning umbrella. Then he hears-- DENISE (on internet) Welcome, my new fat-friendly fan! Vince Jr. looks at his computer, excited. DENISE (on internet) You're now an official member of my club. If you see me at a BBW function in the New York area where I live, you can tell me you're a special member by saying our secret word: BOTERO. VINCE JR. (to himself) Botero. A moment later, an image of a kitchen appears.  45

dialogues.speaker: LIVE KITCHEN IMAGE
dialogues.text: Denise moves around the kitchen, juggling baking pans, cookie sheets etc. Vince Jr. gets up. Backs away from the computer, keeping his eyes on the screen, as if it might vanish. He leaves the room—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and descends the stairs. Looks. Nobody around. He leave

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Vince Jr. exits, hops off the porch and approaches Denise house. The windows are set rather high up. Vince Jr. gets on a concrete block and peers into—

dialogues.speaker: A KITCHEN WINDOW
dialogues.text: There she is, just like on the computer, juggling baking pans, cookie sheets. Vince Jr. stares in fascination. 63. ExT. 59° STREET TRAMWAY NIGHT The Tram that takes you, high above Manhattan, across to Roosevelt Island. As the tram rises into the air.. «we see that it is indeed a starry, starry night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ROOSEVELT ISLAND TRAM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Molly and Vince are the only two on the tram. Vince looks out, a little mystified at where he is and how he got here. As she stares out at the stars—

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The answers are all there. Don’t worry, Vincent. For some reason, you’re very close to God right now. I don’t know why..but you can feel it in the stars. (dawning) Of course! Mercury’s in retrograde.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Mercury's a what?  46

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Mercury—the wing-footed messenger. Represents communication and the process of life. Retrograde: traveling backwards. It happens three or four times a year— and since all backward movement symbol- izes a return to source, our atten- tions turn towards unfinished business. It can be a fine time for completing things. Re-connecting. Settling accounts. (and then) Letting the stars do their plentiful work. Vince looking at her. Something about her way...

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Is it kinda strange that what you say makes sense to me? MOLLY (shakes head no—then) Yes. But everything’s strange, Vincent. When you think of it, acting is one of the strangest things a person could choose to do with themselves. Pretending to be another person—who was dreamed up by a third party! It’s like agreeing to be a marionette. Vince turns this around in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Why you an actress then?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh really. What else could I do? What other profession would accommodate my behavioral problems? VINCE (smiles) Yeah. Sort of like getting paid for being a screw-up.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Perfect. They both look off at the view.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO BACKYARD NIGHT
dialogues.text: Joyce and Tony.  47 JOYCE (resigned) I feel like I spend my whole life trying to please everyone, and all it does is make ‘em mad. My son--Jesus what a pill he’s becomin’! And Vivian. Twenty years of working for that law firm so I could put away enough for her to go to law school after she graduates. You'd think she’d at least talk to me about it. I ask her about her classes and she just shrugs. “Whatever...” And Vince and his ‘poker game’. Does he think I buy that crap? TONY (a little shrug) I grew up with a mother and no father. And my mother hated my father so much for leaving that she took it out on me cause I reminded her of him. Joyce lights another cigarette. Stares off into the yard and blows smoke.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: He started that room three years ago. Bought enough wood and junk to build a forest. That was gonna be his new career—-building stuff. He was all gung-ho and then..pffffttt. (shrugs ) He gets discouraged when things take too long. Like more than an hour. Tony clutches himself against the cool air. Joyce sees th

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Upstairs in my son’s room? There’s a bunch of sweaters. First door on the left. He nods and gets up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony bounds up the stairs and enters 67. VINCE JR.’s ROOM Nobody's home. The lights are out. Only the glow of the computer is on. Tony stares at the screen.  48 DENISE (on internet) Welcome, my new fat-friendly fan! You're now an official member of my club. If you see me at a BBW function in the New York area where I live, you can tell me you're a special member by saying our secret word: BOTERO. Tony scowls at the computer. TONY (to himself) Botero. 68. EXT. DENISE’S KITCHEN WINDOW Vince Jr. watches Denise. VINCE JR. (under) Botero... Then--the concrete block he’s on sways backwards.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY--IT GIVES
dialogues.text: Vince Jr. falls backwards into a fence. Big noise.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Looks up, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Hey! Hello! Who’s out there? Vince Jr. scrambles to his feet, hops over a hedge and ru into his house.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROOSEVELT ISLAND NIGHT
dialogues.text: Molly and Vince sitting on a bench looking at the gloriou Manhattan view.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: So. You been thinkin’ anymore about your “worst secret?”

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I think about it all the time.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You probably got so many interesting secrets—  He lets it hang. 49

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Scads—

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: --it’s hard to tell which one’s the best. (pause, then) I gonna get to hear it? I don’t mean to press you or nothin’, but we got class comin’ up in a few days and...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Where do you live, Vincent?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: The Bronx.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No thonx.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Ogden Nash. Skip it. For all I know, the Bronx is lovely.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Well, my part of it is. S’called City Island. Old fishing village.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Really? (this appeals to her) City..Island. On the one hand a paradox— a peaceful island located within the world’s busiest city. Further, the words stand in stark relief from each other—"city”, so short and abrupt and definite and “island”—exotic, unknowable and with the silent “s”.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I never really thought about it that way. It’s a great spot, though—my grandparents built the house and passed it down. Once you live there you can’t really think of moving anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Every busy city needs an island of peace. Like every busy soul needs a  50 place of repose. A place where we hide from our own frantic stories while they..madly, insanely, obsessively pursue us. Pause. This last was said with a vigor that denotes to Vi another side of Molly, another angle. He looks at her, unafraid and unbashful. Molly looks him right in the eyes Then, she opens her purse and pulls out an envelope. She hands it to Vince.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There it is, Vincent. My secret. He begins to open the envelope. But she stops him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. I need it to stay mine for just a little longer. Once you know it, it’s no longer truly a secret. (mysteriously) There’1l be a moment when it’s obvious. Carry it with you. The moment could come at anytime. Molly and Vince smile at each other. A beat. As they look out at the glittering view of Manhattan—

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh, Vincent. What a wonderful time to have not disappeared. MONTAGE — SUNDAY AT THE RIZZO’S

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: A plume of smoke emanates from the upstairs window. We hear Vince coughing. 71. VINCE JR.’s ROOM He’s asleep with his head on his desk, his computer still on Denise’s website.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Vivian comes crashing in, obviously hungover. She opens the fridge, grabs a bottle of Coke, and chugs it. Goes outside.

dialogues.speaker: BACKYARD
dialogues.text: Vivian passes the garage, pausing as she sees—  51

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Already awake, doing push-ups on the cement floor of the garage room. He doesn’t notice her. She glares at him, mistrust in her eyes. She walks away. Tony keeps doing pushups.

dialogues.speaker: A TINY AREA ON THE SIDE OF THE GARAGE
dialogues.text: hidden from view. Vivian lights a cigarette and stands there, smoking and swigging her Coke. A small window into the garage is open, behind her. Vivian throws an empty pack of matches through the open window behind her. 75. j.INT. GARAGE Tony’s doing push-ups as the matches hit the floor. On the cover: HELL’S HALF ACRE. A caricature of a curvaceous woman in red. He stares at it curiously, as he continues his exercises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince and Tony examining the little room, drinking coffee

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Then I figure we run the pipe through her and tap into the main line. (a little labored) Feels good building something. Don’t it? Tony nods but looks off. He sees—

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: making coffee in the kitchen. She meets his eyes. Tony smiles at her. They each look away, bashfully.

dialogues.speaker: .INT. BACKYARD LATER
dialogues.text: Vince and Tony carrying bags of cement from the rear of the garage to the front. Tony has his shirt off. A large tattoo of a cobra is on his back.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You know, my grandfather built this house. Way back. Before I was born. (pause, then) Came here from the old country and became a fish scaler.  52

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Him and his brother. Couple of real mussel suckers. TONY (puzzled) How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Well, here on City Island, if you come from somewhere else you’re known as a ‘muscle-sucker.’ But if you’re born and raised here you’re a ‘clam-digger.’ Old City Island custom. Tony stares at Vince like: who is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Huh. As Tony grabs another bag, we see the expression on Vince face: he and Tony are not connecting.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GARAGE LATER
dialogues.text: Vince lights up, blowing the smoke through the tiny windo He notices Tony staring at the poster of “The Godfather.”

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: If I could come back as some-body different, it’d be him. TONY (warily) Don Corleone?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: No. Brando. (and then) Always kinda thought being an actor is something I could do. Fact, I’m takin’ this acting class in the city. I guess it’s kind of stupid-I ain’t even told my wife. She thinks I gotta poker game. Tony’s eyes: remembering Joyce’s accusation of the night before.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: And all you really got goin’ is an acting class?  53

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Shh. Don’t tell no-one. He offers a cigarette to Tony, who refuses it. Pause. Vince’s eyes: Vince is interested

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I quit inside.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Yeah, they got that rule now. Must suck.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Plenty other things that are worse. guilty at what he knows must go on.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: We try to keep an eye on things. It’s hard—so many guys, so many groups and gangs. But we see somethin’ goin’ on that we don’t like, believe you me-- TONY (a little icy) I took care of myself.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? TONY (shrugs) I figured as soon as I got to Southcourt I had to act more psycho than everyone else. I mean, I was younger so I had to watch myself. in this. He peers at Tony.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: What’d you do?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I went right up to the ugliest guy I could find and said: “I think I’m pissed off with you but I don’t know why. Do I got a reason?” VINCE (smiles) No shit?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was like: gimme your top ten reasons you’re a piece of shit and I’1l let you know when somethin’ rings a  54 bell. Just don’t lie to me and don’t figure me for one of your sissy-boys who're gonna put out for you, you sadly deformed excuse for humanity posing as a piece of prison garbage. (pause, he shrugs) It worked. They thought I was psycho. I was just..acting. Tony turns away. Keeps working. But Vince looks at Tony. Admiration in his eyes. And yearning to connect to him. 79. j.INT. RIZZO HOUSE Tony wanders over to the living room where he sees

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: She looks up from her book.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Think it’s lunchtime. VIVIAN (an odd grunt) Nhhff. She buries her head in her book. Tony stares at her for a beat. Then he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Brunch time. Vince, Vince Jr. Vivian and Tony sit as Joyce serves up bacon, pancakes etc.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: What time you get in, Vince?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I dunno. Midnight.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Win any money? Playing poker? She makes “quote” signs as she says poker. Vince drops hi fork and stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Okay. That was extremely provocative, mom!  55 VINCE (makes quote signs) What does this mean, huh? As the argument continues--

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S FACE
dialogues.text: He knows the truth of Vince’s whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony shovels dirt from one pile to another. He goes to th

dialogues.speaker: TINY AREA ON THE SIDE OF THE GARAGE
dialogues.text: where he finds Vince sitting on a brick, smoking and read the “OPEN CALL” ad. He blanches when he sees Tony, stubbi his cigarette out.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Relax. Just me. (re: the ad) What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Well, between you and me, okay? (Tony nods) I got this friend who cut this out for me. It’s an open call for some movie--tomorrow morning. But... (pause, smokes) «I don't think I’m gonna do it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Why not? Isn’t that what you wanna do? Try acting?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I’m no actor. Not for real. Anyway, too much trouble. I gotta get the day off from work—tell ‘em some story. And for what? It’ll never amount to nothin’. Tony’s face: not getting Vince’s lassitude.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You should do it. He walks away. Vince stares at the ad.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO HOUSE FRONT PORCH LATER
dialogues.text: Vince Jr. lies on the porch, eating sunflower seeds  56 and spitting the shells onto the lawn. But he’s looking a the house next door. He pulls a cigarette out of his pock and thinks about lighting it when— Vince exits, the ad and his cellphone in his hand. Vince stashes his ad. Vince Jr. hides his cigarette. No privacy here. They regard each other with mutual frustration. VINCE JR. (agitated) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Taking a walk. VINCE JR. I’d join you, dad, but I’m waiting for a crack delivery from a group of black friends I've developed a close relationship to in school. Some might call it... (makes “quote” signs) “a business relationship”. VINCE (didn’t hear him) Good. See you in awhile, son. He walks away, heading down the street. Vince Jr. looks relieved at his being gone and pulls out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce looks out the window. Sees Vince walking away. She grabs her cigarettes from a drawer, steps outside and lights one. Tony is hauling away a pile of old lumber. Hot out. His shirt’s off. Joyce stares at his muscular back. In her eyes: she’s checking him out. As Tony turns and heads back to the house, the lumber in his arms-—- He stops. Sees Joyce. They look at each other. SOMETHING ABOUT THIS LOOK... TONY (nods) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Hey yourself. She holds his eyes. Then turns and goes back into the house. She is twenty years younger in attitude. Tony  57 watches her. Then— He drops the lumber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce enters, stops. Smiles to herself. She doesn’t see Vivian staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, what? Vivian is staring at her mother, breaking her reverie.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Oh, relax. Joyce walks away, blowing her daughter off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is bending down to pick up the lumber he dropped. TONY’S POV Through his knees he sees Denise, the fat neighbor, exiting her back door. Tony looks, head upside down, as she waddles through her garden. Tony gets up. Stares at her. Mind working. He picks up the lumber and walks to the front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince Jr. is about to light his cigarette when

dialogues.speaker: TONY APPEARS
dialogues.text: He places the lumber next to the trash. Looks at Vince Jr A beat. Then Tony says, with a nod to Denise’s house:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Botero? Pause. Vince Jr. looks afraid, like he’s been found out.

dialogues.speaker: BUT IF TONY KNOWS THE SECRET CODE THEN IT MUST BE OKAY. S
dialogues.text: 58 VINCE JR. (nods) Botero. A door slams. They both look over as--

dialogues.speaker: DENISE EXITS HER HOUSE
dialogues.text: heading for her car. She sees Vinnie Jr. and smiles. Vince Jr. stares at her, terrified. She looks puzzled and walks away. Vince Jr. looks to Tony, fear in his eyes. TONY (urging him on, in a whisper) Botero! Should he? Shouldn’t he? Can he? Will he? As she’s about disappear from view— VINCE JR. (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: BOTERO
dialogues.text: Denise stops. Turns. They look at each other. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: I’m making Triple Braised Baby Back Ribs and deep fried potatoes au gratin! (and then) Want to go shopping with me? Vince Jr. gets to his feet. Stares at her. Tony stares at him. Finally: Vince Jr. smiles as he walks over to Denise. Tony watches, quietly pleased at his part in this little exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince on the cell phone, the crumpled “Open Call” ad from Backstage in his hand, a cigarette in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Yeah it’s Vince Rizzo, correctional officer 426. I’m sick and need to take tomorrow off. Matt Cruniff'll cover my desk. All right? (then).. And don't call my house for nothin’. He hangs up. As he walks away he sees—

dialogues.speaker: VINCE JR. AND DENISE
dialogues.text: walking into the A&P together like an old married couple. Vince's eyes: his son and the fat neighbor are friends?  59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince Jr. pushes the basket as Denise fills it up with cartons of fattening food. Vince Jr. stops as he sees—

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: The chubby girl from High School, standing by the diet fo section. Vince Jr. smiles at her. VINCE JR. Hey Cheryl. She turns. His face: preening in a strange way. Cheryl tu and sees Vince Jr. with the super-sized Denise.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Vinnie? Cheryl’s face: despite herself, she is jealous!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CANAL STREET MORNING
dialogues.text: Vince checks the address of the ad. Walks and looks down block. Heads for a building. Sees a line waiting to get i He goes to the Security Man who waits at the head.

VINCE (reading from script) “So make no mistake, Joey. From here on out, I’m watching you. What you do. Who you do? Was it..no. dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Rizzo. VINCE (looks at her) S'that it? She nods. As Vince stands, though, the phone rings.

dialogues.text: Just a moment. She holds up a finger signaling Vince to wait. Listens to the voice on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CASTING DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Absolutely..absolutely..absolutely... (and then) I’ll try. She motions for Vince to come back.

dialogues.text: Are you an actor Mr. Rizzo? Vince looks around.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Uh-not really. I’m a corrections officer.

dialogues.speaker: CASTING DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: A prison guard?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Guess you could call it that.  68

dialogues.speaker: CASTING DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Where do you work?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE

dialogues.speaker: CASTING DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: That one of those..country club prisons? Vince can’t help but be slightly offended. Perhaps this i what was intended?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't call it that, sir, not by a longshot. We got people in there who..lemme put it this way: if you could see inside their minds and what they’re thinking..you wouldn't be thinking of no golf game.

dialogues.speaker: CASTING DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Tell me more about what you do. What's a typical day like?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Typical? Well..no such animal. Some days it’s rote and tote-you know, roll call and work duty. Nothin’ much happens. Other days... (pause, then) other days there’s trouble. Gangs get outta control. We gotta lockdown. The boys and girls have their little bitch spats just like in the real world only they jump some bones and try to make their mettle on the new recruits. Ugly stuff. Sometimes guys come in and I say to myself “Two words for you: bye-bye.” Cause I know they ain’t getting out the same as they came in, if you know what I mean.

dialogues.text: You know this scene we just read? Could you do it in your own words? Vince thinks. Shrugs. What the hell.  Tony’s words. 69

dialogues.text: My own words? Well, I didn’t read the whole script or nothin’, but it seems like this Joey Zambooli thinks he’s got the goods on the guy I play. Frankie— (consults script) Grinucci. Which makes this Zambooli the worst kind of creep.

dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.text: Well, like for instance, where I work? It’s all about power. And guys like Zambooli come at the new guys and try to intimidate them. And if you don’t get in their face fast, they’1ll have you on all fours sucking the cement. (pause, then) Pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: CASTING DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Well.. I’d put my hand on this Joey Zambooli’s shoulder and sorta from nowhere I’d go: “I think I’m pissed off with you but I don’t know why. Do I got a reason?”

dialogues.text: Well, when I was ‘bout nineteen, I met Nan who was older. And she was hot for me and I was hot to get away from my family. We drank at the same bar. And before you know it..we were living at her place in Jersey. (pause, then) Strange how things happen when you're not even looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony drives, Reggae dance hall BLARING from the radio. He grooves along with the radio, cruises in and out of traff and generally seems to be having a great time. Freedom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce is brushing her teeth. But she’s out of toothpaste. She opens a closet door and finds VINCE’S BOOK “An Actor Prepares”. She stares at it, suspiciously. Open it. Inside is a card, on which is written MOLLY CHARLESWORTH-917-463-3742. Joyce stares at the number, having at last found the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince and Molly. VINCE (finishing his tale) And then the next things she’s pregnant and by then I knew she was bad news for me and I tried to get her to get rid of the kid. (remembering the moment) And she said to me: “I know you'll be leaving soon anyway. And I ain't get- ting left with nothing for myself.” And that’s how I knew she was having the kid and I had to just..do what I had to do. (pause, then) I had seventy-five hundred bucks saved from when I started working with my dad on his boat. It was gonna put me through City College. I sent it to her instead. Then I got hooked up with the prison  80 stuff—figured I needed a good steady income and pension. I never heard from Nan again.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: And did you ever tell anyone else in your family?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Nah. I didn’t wanna burden nobody else. Besides, I wasn’t too proud of taking off.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Leaving’s never pretty. No matter how you do it. A beat. Then Molly's cell phone rings. She answers it.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Hello...Hello... But there’s nobody there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce hangs up the phone, pain and anger in her eyes. She mimics Molly’s accent.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Hulew! Hulew! Bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly and Vince. She hangs up the cell. An odd look in he eye.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: There was nobody there.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I hate these things—I’m always getting’ wrong numbers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't a wrong number, it was... an announcement. A ring—a bell, an indication.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Of what?  8 MOLLY (smiles) Now, Vincent. Now’s the time. You do have it on you, don’t you? Vince’s face: blank for a moment. Then he realizes she means: the envelope! The secret! He pulls it out.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Your secret? Yeah, course. (before he opens it) You sure? She nods. Doesn't take her eyes off him. He opens it. Ins is a single photograph.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHOTO
dialogues.text: is of three very young children, all grouped on a couch, smiling at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Who are they? MOLLY (beat, then) My three secrets. Vince takes this in-trying to connect the Molly he knows with the Molly that is being revealed. She looks him in t eye. Her looks says it all. He takes it in. Then, quietly

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: With my husband in Schenectady.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Schenectady? Upstate? What were you doin’ up there?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The real question is: what am I doing down here? (and then) That’s where I’m from, Vincent. Born and raised.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Your family own some big business up there or somethin’?  82

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: My father was the janitor at the grade school. My mother left when I was six. (the photo) And their mother left a year ago. Big beat. Vince connecting the enchantress he knows with the woman she’s revealing herself to be. VINCE (pause, then) Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: To see if it was possible to pretend the past never existed. (and finally) Don’t hate me, Vincent. I thought if anyone might understand, it would be you. Vince looks at the picture. Then at her. In his eyes, sadness—as much at himself as at her. He extends his hand. She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jeep swerves in and out of traffic, at double the speed of the other drivers. It takes a sharp right and heads off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jeep pulls in. Plenty of other rowdy cars in the park lot. Tony parks and gets out. Feels fucking great! 137. INT. HELL’S HALF ACRE Tony enters. A bouncer stands at a curtain. Behind him is visible the bar and the elevated dance floor. Stripper undulate. The bouncer looks at Tony.

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: You got I.D.? Tony pulls out his wallet. Produces a prison I.D. card. The Bouncer shrugs. Nods him in. Tony enters.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: Heads for the bar. Catches Bruno the Bartender’s eye.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Heineken.  83 Bruno nods, pours a cold one. Tony puts down a twenty. Turns and looks at the stage longingly. Three strippers, pole dancing. Hot stuff. Tony stares, trying to drink in a good long look. Then—

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S FACE
dialogues.text: --something funny here. He moves back into the main room staring at one of the strippers. Yes, it’s--

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Wrapping her legs around the pole.

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S FACE
dialogues.text: He can’t put it together. He moves closer to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Wrapping legs, shaking booty. Customers pant. She opens h eyes. And-bingo! SEES TONY.

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S FACE
dialogues.text: Not wanting to be seen but frozen in place.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN'S FACE
dialogues.text: Not wanting to be seen, but frozen in place. They each stare bug eyed at each other. Then she jumps of the stage and races off. Tony goes out the front way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivian emerges in a bathrobe and slippers. Slams the door behind her, grasps the wall and closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Shit. 138. EXT. FRONT DOOR OF HELL’S HALF ACRE DAYLIGHT Tony emerges, looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Shit.  84 The bouncer stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: THE REAR OF THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: where Vivian is trying to calm down. She furtively looks over her shoulder out toward--

dialogues.speaker: THE PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: where she stares ahead at—

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE'S JEEP
dialogues.text: Vivian's eyes: filled with suspicion. She walks to the ca Opens the door and then the glove compartment. The handcuffs fall out. So does a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: watches Vivian discover the jeep. Fear in his eyes. He briefly looks like he might flee. But this is not an option. After squirming a little, he heads toward her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Uh. Hi. VIVIAN (furious) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, guess I could ask the same question.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Does my mother know you have her car?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Does she know you’re a stripper? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Give me the key. (pause, then) Do you even have it? (pause, then) You don’t have it. (a smile now) You stole my mother’s car! Didn't you? Oh, you loser! Tony’s eyes: real fear. She takes the cell phone and dials 911.  85

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I really think before you do anything we should talk.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: About what? Economic theory? (into cell) Hello, I’d like to report a stolen car. Yeah, I can hold. (and then) J-A-I-L, here he comes!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I thought you went to college.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Who says I don’t go to college?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What's this, your part-time gig?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I don’t have to tell you anything.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So you do go to college?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I do? I mean—yes!I do but...shit, why are you even here? TONY (the matchbook) Cause I found this in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Shit! Well, so what? My parents aren’t gonna listen to anything you have to say once they find out you stole their car! (into phone) Hi, yes. My mother’s car was stolen. License plate number is... She doesn’t know it. She goes to the back of the car. But Tony runs to the back of the car and stands in front of the plate as Vivian tries to read it.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Hold on! She runs to the front of the car. But Tony sprints there first and once again obscures the license plate  86 with his body. In frustration, she turns to run to the ba again but—

dialogues.speaker: SHE TRIPS
dialogues.text: falling on her face and sending the cell phone skidding across the asphalt. and grabs it. Tony makes a diving leap for the phone

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: STRIPPING ISN’T AGAINST THE LAW!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: DOES THAT MEAN IT’S OKAY FOR ME TO TELL YOUR PARENTS ‘BOUT WHAT YOU DO?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: DON'T CALL ME THAT! I’M NOT A HOOKER.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: SHOWIN’ YOUR TITS FOR MONEY, WHAT'S

dialogues.speaker: I GOT SUSPENDED FROM SCHOOL AND LOST
dialogues.text: MY SCHOLARSHIP! IT’S JUST SO I CAN

dialogues.speaker: HAVE TO TELL MY PARENTS WHAT HAPPENED
dialogues.text: 87 TONY (laughing at this) AND I’M A LOSER, HUH? She hits Tony hard on his face. This stops him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY STANDS
dialogues.text: throwing her to the ground. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh, the hell with all of you.

dialogues.speaker: HE THROWS THE CELL PHONE
dialogues.text: across traffic and the highway. Vivian looks stunned as T marches to the car. He grabs the handcuffs, cuffs one end himself and the other end to Vivian’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m taking your mom’s car back with you in it-—so you know I really delivered. And only you know I took it and only I know you work here. That’s the deal forever. Un- less one of us blows it. (then) That’s how it works where I’ve been and that’s how it’s gonna work with you and me. Got it, Vivian? She gets it. But she looks at the handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Take these off.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sorry. But your behavior towards me in the past few days hasn’t exactly earned my trust. Vivian's hostile glare at Tony is mixed with something el the guilty knowledge that he’s right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony drives with his un-handcuffed hand. Hostile silence.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Why did my father bring you home?  88

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Hostile silence. Then—

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: What was goin’ on with you and my mom?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Are you gonna tell them that I’m a—

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I gave you my word, didn’t I? My word is my word. Which is something you and your jerkoff family probably never heard of. Bunch of lyin’ psychos. Tony is finished. He stares ahead at the road. Vivian doesn’t react overtly. But in the mirror we see that her eyes are welling up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Rambler pulls up. Vince and Molly get out. Molly look at the little clapboard house and smiles. But Vince notices the empty parking space, the lack of Je

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: She ain’t home. Maybe she went out for some food. They mount the stairs and enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince and Molly in the living room. Vince unpacks his pockets of keys, change. Molly sits on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Now I’m thinkin’, when she comes in I’m gonna say: "Joyce, it’s time we had a talk.”  89

dialogues.speaker: RIZZO BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Joyce is lying in bed. She hears Vince’s voice, gets up f the bed and heads for the

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Where she sees Vince and Molly from the top of the stairs She looks puzzled. They cannot see her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Vincent, darling, it’s the wrong way. Women—they feel challenged by too much honesty too quickly. Joyce's face: what the hell?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Trust me, twenty-years I’ve been with her. I know what I’m talkin’ about—

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Vincent, darling, thirty years I've been a woman. Let me handle her. We begin casually. No mention at all of anything unusual going on. Before she can even think to ask what I’m doing here, she’ll be thanking me for having come into your life. Joyce's face: enough is enough. Slowly she walks down the stairs. Molly sees her first. Looks puzzled. Motions to Vince who turns.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Hey, you’re home! Joyce nods, face blank with shock and outrage.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Vince, I’m home. Where I live. (looks at Molly) Who's this? Molly stands and extends an arm.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Molly Charlesworth. A pleasure! Joyce doesn’t take her hand. Uncomfortable pause. Molly withdraws it and looks at Vince.  90

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Molly here..well, we got somethin’ to tell you. (flustered—to Molly) Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I got something to tell you, Vince. VINCE (eyes narrow) Oh yeah? Well, what we got to tell is really very important here.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Oh really? Well what I got to tell is pretty important too.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Well..is it more important or less important than what we gotta tell?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: How would I know that Vince? I don’t know what you have to tell me. Beat. She has led him successfully down the path of total incomprehension. MOLLY (helpfully) May I say--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Don’t say a word, bitch. Gasp. Molly looks astounded. Vince looks astounded. Joyce is calm with righteousness. But the pot has begun to boil

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Joyce! What the—

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Prick! Into my house you bring her, huh? Into my own house where I raised your two children you bring this.. thing of yours. Well lemme tell you Vince, I’m gonna do you a big favor. I’m gonna put both of you outta your misery here. I’m not gonna be insulted in my own house. I want you gone, Vince. Out of my life! No more running around behind my back. No more cheap, dirty lies! No more lying in bed wondering who else has been touching my husband. No more lying to myself that it doesn’t matter.  91 I found passion today, Vince, and it felt great. I was touched and kissed and held and it felt like you haven't made me feel in years! Molly and Vince are watching the monologue, mouths agape. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: What are you talkin’ here?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I’m talking about Tony! Big beat.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You did somethin’..with Tony?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: More than “something”, Vince! Vince's eyes: thunderstruck. He suddenly rushes off into the kitchen. The sound of him wretching over the sink. Joyce looks perplexed. Molly doesn’t. She knows what’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh dear. Greek in scope... Just then—

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: That’s my car! Joyce watches as Tony and Vivian mount the stairs, still hand-cuffed to each other.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: stumbles back into the room, dabbing his face with a wet cloth. What he sees is:

dialogues.speaker: TONY AND VIVIAN HANDCUFFED TOGETHER
dialogues.text: And she’s in a robe.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE'S FACE
dialogues.text: Veins are popping. The thought that Tony has had both his wife and daughter is too much. He grabs a BUTCHER KNIFE A CHARGES TONY.  92

dialogues.speaker: AGGGGGHHHHHH
dialogues.text: Everyone screams. Vince lunges for Tony. Tony jumps out o the way, dragging Vivian with him. Vince lands on the floor in front of the door. Joyce grabs the handcuffs, trying to keep them from running.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Vince—get the key! Vince gets up, fumbles in his pockets and pulls out his keys. Hands them to Joyce and wields the knife at Tony wh looks terrified. Joyce unlocks Vivian who runs across the room. Tony shoves Vince away and dashes for the back door handcuffs dangling from his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO BACKYARD NIGHT
dialogues.text: As Tony jumps out, Vince comes after him with the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sonavabitch bastard—you better run! I’m gonna kill ya!! I’m gonna kill ya!! 145. INT. DENISE’S HOUSE NIGHT Vince Jr., Cheryl and Denise are eating M&M’s and watchin TV. Vince’s voice pierces the walls. Vince Jr. sits up. VINCE JR. Dad? Concerned looks. He gets up and goes to the window. Denis and Cheryl follow. They look—

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO BACKYARD NIGHT
dialogues.text: Vince has Tony trapped by the garage.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You piece of shit—you screwed my wife? My daughter? Who was next, my son?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I didn’t screw nobody!  93

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BACK PORCH
dialogues.text: Molly, Joyce and Vivian stare at the scene.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: He didn’t screw nobody! (then—looks at Joyce) Did he? Joyce, stymied by the goings-ons, can’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE AND TONY
dialogues.text: Vince is wielding the knife, trying to trap Tony who's dodging and feinting for his life.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Put it down, man, put it down! You're making a huge mistake!

dialogues.speaker: HE HURLS THE BUTCHER KNIFE
dialogues.text: It sails over the fence, cleaning missing Tony and disappearing from sight. VINCE JR. Jeez, Dad. Pretty lame.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: There. No more knives, okay? (he approaches Vince) Peace. Okay? I don’t know what you think happened here—but peace. Okay, Vince? Then we'll talk. He’s holding his hands out like a suspect apprehended. The handcuffs dangle from his wrist. VINCE (pause, then) Okay peace. Vince holds up his hands in mimicry of Tony. Then—

dialogues.speaker: VINCE GRABS THE HANDCUFF
dialogues.text: And yanks Tony to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, Vince!  94 Tony howls in pain as Vince, in expert prison guard mode, subdues him, twists his wrist and drags him across the cement yard. He attaches the other end of the handcuff to the wooden deck. Then he runs to the garage, grabs the other pair of handcuffs and chains Tony’s leg. Tony is now chained, on all fours, like a wild animal. Vince whacks him across the face.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Stop it! VINCE (whacks him again) Bastard!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! As Vince winds up to whack him again—

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Is moved to action. She jumps off the back porch and throws her tiny frame onto Vince’s back. Pounds him with her fists.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Stop it, Vince! He didn’t do nothing! Vince spins around, trying to get Joyce off his back but she stays attached.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: What about your Goddam passion and all that crap? The two of the them are now arguing while she rides piggy back on him.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: So what about yours, Vince? Your Molly Ringwald over there who's gonna take care of everything for you and who I’m supposed to thank for “being in your life”. You bring your filthy girlfriend into my house—

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: She’s not my girlfriend! Joyce looks up at Molly who, appalled, shakes her head.  95

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m his manager.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: His what?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: For the Scorsese movie with De Niro.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: What De Niro movie?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: That’s what I was trying to tell you! I’m gonna be in a Robert De Niro movie directed by Martin Scorsese! Beat. All look at each other, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: What kind of bullshit is that?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Actually, he hasn't been signed yet. But he auditioned today and apparently made quite an impression. They’ve called him back.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You auditioned for a movie today?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Yeah and Molly here—well..she sorta... (pause, sigh, what the hell) she’s a friend of mine. We’re in acting class together. She told me to go this audition here so I went.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Acting class? When do you go to acting class?

dialogues.speaker: WHEN I PLAY POKER
dialogues.text: Pause. Nobody can figure this out.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s a ruse, you see. He didn’t want you to know because Vincent has feelings of shame and inferi- ority about his ambitions.  96

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Is this just a lot of crap?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: No, it’s the truth. And I wanted to tell you about it but I knew you'd be mad about lying to you about the class so Molly here said she’d come along and..pretend to be my manager! Joyce dismounts Vince. Stares at him. He stares back at her. So much frustration, jealousy, and sheer anger.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You know what honey? I don’t give a shit! In fact, I don’t give two shits! You don’t believe me? Fine with me. You got a few things to answer for yourself, here. (he looks at Tony) What's goin’ on here?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Nothing, I was just..I was..just.. (feels scared) You're leaving me..for her. Aren't you? She nods to Molly. Vivian looks at Molly as if for the fi time.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Oh come on. Dad couldn’t get her!

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You keep your mouth shut, little girl. What are you doin’ running around with that animal in your robe there? Pause. From the ground:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Tell him. (looks up at Vivian) Tell him! She shakes her head, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I was back at school and I—  97

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Tell him the truth! You're all so sick, just tell each other the Goddam truth! Joyce and Vince staring at their daughter. Tony looks as well. He and Vivian lock eyes. It’s clear she won’t give first so-

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I stole your car. You hear me? I boosted your Goddam car so I could take off and get away from all your crap! I couldn’t live here another thirty days if my life depended on it. And if you want to send my ass back to the cage, be my guest!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You stole the car?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with her? Tony stares at Vivian, who looks back at him. Beat. She realizes it’s her turn now. Tension: Vince is preparing to whack Tony again. Vivian must come clean or he will be hurt! As Tony stars at her—

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I'm.a strrr..a strr..stripper. JOYCE (as if she misheard her) A what? (and then) Oh my God. You’re a what?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: She's a stripper! She takes her clothes off for money! Okay? Vince and Joyce can’t believe what they’re hearing. So each chooses not to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: She is not!

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You lying piece of shit! He whacks Tony hard. Vivian can’t take it. As Vince winds up to whack him again—  98

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Stop it, dad-it’s true! Big beat. Vince looks at his daughter. His eyes go to her chest. So do Joyce’s eyes. So do Tony’s eyes. Vivian tries to make her chest look smaller. Stares back defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I paid for them myself! All right?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: No. No, you go to school, honey. You got that scholarship—

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: They took it away. (and then) I can re-apply next year but no more scholarship. I gotta pay for it myself. And I’m gonna.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Why'd they take it away?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Because my friend..because this guy I know... (pause, finally) Because I screwed up. Me. I screwed up and got caught with..pot in my room. “Pot.” That is such a stupid little word. Long pause. The family stares at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: They kicked you outta school and took away your scholarship over an ounce? Jeez. When I was at Oneonta, I couldn’t get back into my dorm after a weekend unless I was carrying an ounce! Vivian and her mother lock eyes. She sees at once that he mother would have been her best friend if she’d let her. Tears well up!  99

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Oh, mom, I’m such a screw-up! VINCE (not as moved) Wait a minute, here! What about this stealing my car? You know I could have you back inside in about ten minutes if I want to-- TONY (at Vince) Fine, do it. At least everyone's honest. You’re so scared of your wife you don’t even smoke in front of her! JOYCE (looks up) Vince—you smokin’?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: No, I quit!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Liar! And you got your wife thinking you gotta girlfriend cause you're too scared to tell her you want to go to acting class. (and then) And the whole time, you got some weird agenda with me and you won't tell me what it is! Why’d you get me outta prison? Why’d you bring me here?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I told you-I was a friend of your mothers!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: My mother never had a friend so good they'd do me a right turn! Everybody hated her! She’s a whore and a bitch and if she put you up to getting me out— VINCE (raging)

dialogues.speaker: ON HER BEFORE YOU WERE BORN
dialogues.text: There it is! Tony and Vince stare at each other, each mutually shocked at what’s now out in the open. Molly is wide eyed.  100 Joyce tries to take this in. Vivian stands, frozen, staring at Tony. Tony is hyperventilating, on all fours. So is Vince, standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Are...are...you..my...father? Big beat. Quietly, as befits the moment— VINCE (nods) Yeah, Tony. I’m your..father. Holding back tears as he says it. Tony holding back tears as he hears it. Joyce looks shocked. JOYCE (sotto) Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Mom? Joyce shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Said like: close call. Vince turns and stares at her. His eyes are pleading for an answer that won’t kill him.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Honey..what happened here? Meaning Tony. Her eyes plead forgiveness back.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Nothing, Sweetie. (and then, looking at Tony) Your son was a perfect gentleman. Tony’s eyes meet Joyce’s: they know what they each shared and why their day together was ultimately a success. JOYCE (back at Vince) Anyway, how long you known about this guy?  101 Meaning Tony. Vince looks at her. Shrugs through his emotion.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: I meant to tell you the whole thing, sweetie. Years ago. Really. There’s so much I been wanting to tell you. It just..never seems like the right time... Tears forming in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I thought you were just..sick of me.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Sick? No. Scared of you maybe but not sick of you. You’re..you’re.. He looks around. Sees Molly. She pantomimes BREATHING DEEPLY. Vince remembers.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You're the air that I breathe. They embrace each other. Oh, how they embrace. Like two people who are so happy to have each other back. Molly watches Vince and Joyce. Something in this moment is affecting her as well. Very gradually—

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY BACKS AWAY INTO THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Her face: she is done here.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FRONT PORCH OF RIZZO HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Molly exits. Looks down the little City Island street. As the song continues, we watch Molly walk alone into the encroaching evening.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO BACKYARD NIGHT
dialogues.text: Joyce and Vince hugging each other.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Will somebody please unlock me? Vince turns and stares at his son. Tony stares up at his father. Long beat. Tony stares at his father. A tear glistens in his eye. Vince unlocks Tony. Tony stands. A long look between the two-—wordless, but filled with apology and a never-ending  102 sense of how weird life can be. And then Tony and Vince hug each other. Vince grabs Joyce And even Tony and Vivian grab each other. VIVIAN (amazed) You're my brother! No wonder I...I.. (searching, then) I hate you so much! At that moment— DENISE’S WINDOW OPENS UP Vince Jr. stands there. As Cheryl and Denise looks on- VINCE JR. (pleased) You were right mom. Dad did have sex with Tony’s mom! Joyce looks at her son. Long beat. Then—she starts to lau The more she tries to stop laughing the more she cries! Vince watches this. His tears start to mix with his laughter. That odd mixture again. He cries and laughs onto Joyce’s shoulder. Now the whole family is laughing and crying together, as the sun sets over the Bronx.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PORT AUTHORITY BUS TERMINAL MORNING
dialogues.text: The sun just breaking. A bus pulls out of the terminal gates. In a window of the bus we see—

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sitting, watching as Manhattan recedes from view, the sun breaking over the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Class is being held. The stage is empty. Michael Malakov says:

dialogues.speaker: MALAKOV
dialogues.text: Molly Charlesworth. VINCE (pause, then) She’s not here.  103 Malakov turns to Vince.

dialogues.speaker: MALAKOV
dialogues.text: Was she your partner?

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. She left town, I think. MALAKOV (shrugs) Hm. Well, class, you now have one less actor in New York City to worry about stealing your role. People applaud sarcastically. But not Vince. MALAKOV (cont. ) Vince? You ready? Vince stands and walks to the stage... He looks out at the faces in the audience. Seems calm and sure of himself. And, after taking a pause, he begins.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: You asked me my worst secret. My most personal secret. The secret of all my secrets. I get it. (pause, then) But first..I’m Vince Rizzo and I want to begin by telling you about where I live. Now we realize that the opening monologue was, in fact, a flashback from this point. Joyce Rizzo stands at the back the class. Looking at her husband with a different set of eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET CORNER DAY
dialogues.text: Vince exits a deli with three friends. They all bid each other a casual farewell. As Vince walks away—

dialogues.speaker: THE SOUND OF A GUN GOING OFF
dialogues.text: Vince looking scared. Bullets are in the air. And THREE BULLETS STRIKE VINCE. He collapses on the sidewalk, blood pouring from his stomach, the look of unexpected death filling his eyes. A very long pause. During which we, in the audience, migh well be thinking: what the hell just happened to this movie?  104

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO BACKYARD DAY
dialogues.text: A yard party in progress. The whole Rizzo family-Joyce, Vivian, Vince Jr. and Tony. EVERYONE EXCEPT VINCE. Joyce raises a glass of red wine in a solemn toast.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: To my husband.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET CORNER DAY
dialogues.text: Vince, still lying on the street “dead”, blood pouring fr him. Finally he hears— SCORSESE'’S VOICE Cut. Great! Thanks, everyone. Vince opens an eye. He’s helped up by some of the crew. H moment on screen—getting murdered by Martin Scorcese—is over. Costume and props and assistants help him up, clean him, congratulate him. He looks proud. Vince is now a working actor.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIZZO BACKYARD DAY
dialogues.text: Joyce, continuing her toast. A smile now appearing on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: To my husband. The best actor in City Island. Now we see Vince, standing at the barbeque. He smiles at Joyce. Then Tony steps up with his toast.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: To my father. The only actor in City Island. He smiles at the man who is his dad. And his dad smiles b at his boy.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.0)
dialogues.text: Somehow, with Tony’s appearance a lot of good things happened. I shoulda looked for him years ago. Everyone seated at the picnic table. Behind them the view of the water. New York City in the distance, clear as a friggin’ bell.  The food is on heads. 105

dialogues.speaker: VINCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every busy city needs an island of peace. Just as every busy soul needs a place of repose. Before, City Island was the place where I hid from my own life. (and then) Now it’s home. For everyone. What else you need? the plates. Grace time. Everyone bows their

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. We thank you for this meal here... And to show our faith and unity... a moment of silence. As Vince says Grace, we see their faces. Vince. Joyce. Vivian. Vince Jr. Tony. Vince and Joyce look at each other. This is their bond. This is their life.

dialogues.speaker: VINCE
dialogues.text: All right. Let’s eat! The Rizzo family starts passing the food. The water in th background and the distance. the forever majestic skyline of Manhattan in Ain't life grand?
